The TGRP is designed to provide NPC by 1998 with the means of operating a major EHV transmission grid facility serving over 80% of the electricity demand in the Philippines, by interconnecting over 5000 MW of power station capacity in Luzon and Visayas. When the project is completed, EHV overhead transmission lines will extend over 2000 km from the 1000 MW Sual power station in Northern Luzon through submarine cables to the island of Panay in Western Visayas. Facilities will also be provided to manage grid operations from a National Load Dispatch Center (NLDC) located in the new headquarters of the proposed NPC Transmission Company (TRANSCO). The project comprises four components as follows: (i) the northwest Luzon 500 kV transmission extension and associated system reinforcement component; (ii) the TRANSCO HQ, National Load Dispatch Center (NLDC), communications and protection Facilities component; (iii) the Visayas subtransmission component; and Techical Assistance to support (iv) implementation of the above, NPC privatization and MIS facilities. The following provides a summary of the technical details and the scope of the project including implementation arrangements as described in NPC's Project Implementation Plan of September 15, 1995. North West Luzon 500 kV Transmission Extension and Associated EHV System Reinforcement Component 2. The Bank financed 500 kV transmission line component is designed to complement new investment in northwest Luzon of about US$ 2 billion for generation and transmission projects financed by ADB, KfW, Japan Eximbank and the private sector. The line will be required to evacuate electricity from the first 300 MW unit at Masinloc by end 1997; followed by a second 300 MW unit at Masinloc and a 1000 MW unit at Sual, both planned for commissioning in mid 1998. Parallel financing has been arranged with ADB for the 230/500 kV substations, and KfW for the 230 kV lines interconnecting Masinloc. During the period of construction of the 500kV northwest transmission system NPC will also be reinforcing a number of 230 kV substations supplying the greater Manila region subtransmission netwvorks to cater for the increase in demand. Expansion requirements for eight of these substations will be financed under the project. In addition Bank funding will provide for additional resources to support 500 kV development under the ongoing Leyte Luzon project (Loan 3646-PH) through supplemental financing to cover the increased cost of the 500 kV Naga Tayabas line. The main technical contributions of the proposed project are to increase the transfer capacity of the EHV transmission of bulk energy to the major load center of Metro Manila and improve the reliability of the transmission system as a whole. These technical improvements would provide economic benefits associated with: (i) the evacuation of lower cost energy from the Sual and Masinloc plants and an initial hydropower development in Northem Luzon; and (ii) important savings in reserve capacity requirements which would be reduced by about 10% as system reliability improves. The first benefit is directly associated to the proposed project. The second benefit is attributed to the overall transmission interconnection program which includes, in addition to the 500/230 kV transmission system of the proposed project, the first and second stages of EHV interconnection investments in Leyte and Visayas. As it is not possible to separate reserve capacity benefits for different interconnection investments the project's economic rate of return is calculated for two approaches. Namely: A. Northwest 500/230 kV. An assessment of the proposed northwest 500/230 kV transmission system where benefits are limited to the economic value of incremental sales from Sual. Masinloc and initial hydropower development (up to 2050 MW in total). The cost stream comprises investments in transmission and substations of the proposed project, corresponding operation and maintenance costs and the cost of energy evacuated from northem Luzon. Approach A comprises the principal part of the proposed project (85% of total investment) and part of its benefits. In this respect, approach A provides a minimum measure (lower bound) of the project's economic viability; and B. Interconnection Program. An evaluation of the transmission overall interconnection program, including all components of the proposed project (i.e., the northwest 500/230kV transmission line and substations, the load dispatch center and the Visayas 138kV grid extension) plus the first and second stages of the EHV interconnection investrnents in Leyte and Visayas. Approach A is a subset of approach B, in this sense approach B includes additional costs and benefits. It considers in addition to the incremental sales benefits, the benefits stemming from a reduction in reserve capacity requirements (which can be attributed partially to the proposed project but are not separable). Costs include investments in the said components, corresponding operation and maintenance costs and the cost of energy from northem Luzon. 2. For all cases costs are expressed in 1995 constant values. Financial flows are converted to economic costs by: (i) netting out taxes and other domestic transfers, (ii) expressing import components at CIF prices, and (iii) applying a conversion factor of 0.93 to local costs in order to express them in equivalent border prices. 3. The economic rate of return (ERR) is computed on the basis of the net benefit flow considering benefits and costs as identified above. Incremental electricity sales are limited to the future generation of committed projects and are valued at the current bulk energy tariff of US.cents 6.98 /kWh, ignoring consumers surplus. The cost of energy evacuated from Northem Luzon is valued at US. cents 5.8/kWh. Investment savings from reduced reserve requirements (in approach B only) are valued at US$750/kW, an estimate for the weighted average of gas turbines and coal plants' capital costs. It is estimated that capacity savings will reach 2150 MW in a period of six years, beginning in 1999. Average energy losses of the proposed transmission system are estimated at 3.i%. 4. The intemal economic rate of return of the project is estimated to lie betveen 20.3% and 27.2%. This range is based on approaches A and B which render the lower and upper values, respectively. The economic viabilitv of the project was tested against three adverse assumptions associated with project risks: (i) 15% increase in the investment cost; (ii) a delay of ninc moths in the implementation of the project, including the

This means, for example, that those who do not own the land on which their house is built -- tenant farmers, households granted use rights by landlords, and squatters - did not receive compensation for their house lots and were often unable to find house lots to relocate their houses. doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Transmission Grid Reinforcement Project are to: 1) evacuate power from major generation plants at Sual and Masinloc, both expected to be operational in 1998; 2) reinforce overloaded substations and extend the extra high voltage (EHV) grid in Northwest Luzon and Western Visayas; and 3) strengthen the transmission system and load dispatch operations to support creation of an autonomous transmission subsidiary (TRANSCO), which may later be privatized. The project has four main components: 1) improvement of the trasmission in Northwest Luzon; 2) installation of a new National Load Dispatch Center (NLDC) including communications, metering, and protection equipment in Luzon and the Visayas; 3) reinforcement of the systems in Negros, Panay and Cebu ; and 4) provision of experts services and equipment.
